div1.p: Carter describes her progress and the assistance she has received tracking down references for the History of Yellow Fever manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, February 8, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
February 8, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I have just put in another very full week's work for Dr. Frost
on the bibliographic cards, including night work with Miss Brown.

I have also received, and will later take over to Dr. Frost,
a most interesting, and highly technical! letter from Dr. Morley (a
sequiter of our interview of Dec. 12/28) re certain excerpts from the
Book of Chilam Balam of ChumayelTizimin. There is no use sending it to Dr.
Frost as, while the two of us could go over it in short order, it
would take him considerably longer by himself to get “oriented” on the
subject of these particular excerpts--time which he might otherwise be
spending on consecutive editing.of the History of Yellow Fever. Also, I hope to go over to Baltimore
sometime in the[unclear] comparatively near future, Mrs. Frost having called me
up on the subject of spending a week-end with them night before last.
I have almost finished another “unit” of material since the one of which
I wrote you in my letter of January 26th., and am “working my head off”--
if one can do so on an “Underwood!”--to finish it:- putting in the ex-
tra verbatim quotations and Memoranda needed to make them clearer than
would have been necessary could I have worked with Dr. Frost for the long consecutive
time he had planned last fall (when instead he had the “flu.”) Now with lec-
tures, “flu” investigations etc. his time is more broken up and, as I
wrote you before, many of the cards are being retyped in a manner to
make them clearer to one less “saturated” than myself (and Miss Brown)
with our original sources of reference.

I spent a good part of to-day at the Library of the Surgeon
General of the Army and the Library of Congress respectively. This I
did because I wished to renew some books at the S. G.'s Library, Colonel
Colonel
-2-
Ashburn having allowed me to continue the privelege of taking books
home after I gave up the table on which they were reserved for me at
the Library. I had a delightful talk with Colonel Ashburn, indeed
going back to the Library was almost like going “home,” everyone had
been so very kind and helpful to Miss Brown and myself, from Colonels
Ashburn and Colonel Garrison to the guards, messengers and “char-ladies,” with the I
of whom we were well acquainted, as we frequently reached the Library during the Lpast
summer before they did. Of course, our medical references were prac-
tically completed early last fall, but Mr. Neumann has kept a copy of a
few very elusive ones to try to trace for us, (the same arelist I sent Mr. van Wesep, Dr. L. O Howard,
etc. and from which the late Dr. Harrison G. Dyar and myself finally
“ran down” a couple of Portuguese refs., working together one day.) Mr.
Neumann has been very kind to us, indeed his ordering the copy of Villalba
was a life-saver!

Attended to some necessary details at the Library of Congress also
indeed expected to write to you from there but someone has “hypothecated”
my typewriting table. It was quite natural, as I've done no typing there
for a long time, my standard Underwood, at home, being far better fitted
for work on bibliographic cards than my Remington portable. At that I've
had to have them both readjusted twice and the number of ribbons they “eat up”
is a caution!

By the way, would it be asking too much of your Comptroller to
ask him if he could let me know how much money I received from the I. H.
D. in 1928? reminding him that I sent back a half time salary check from
the Hopkins for $150.00 when I was there on sick leave without pay. In-
cidentally, I have come to the conclusion that I can never afford the
“luxury” of another long illness, though I might still be able to “pull
off” a “satisfactory, simple funeral.” However, until the book is fin-
ished I shall look ahead to no more distant futures, and at present I am
am
-3-
“sufficiently alive”--too much so, as regards the neuritis. However,
it is not interfering with the typing in the least, the more painful
motions being those connected with writing by hand or lifting anything
even a glass of water or a book. I've gotten quite expert at using my
left hand, however. To return to the beginning of this paragraph, I
want the data re salary paid me in 1928 in order to make out my income
tax return. I could figure it out myself from check book stubs, but
I hate to take the time from the work for Dr. Frost. However, if it
is not in order for a person on a half time basis to ask for this data (formerly
sent me unsolicited) of course I can, as I said, straighten it out myself.

With very best remembrances to yourself and hoping that we
shall see you in Washington some time when you do not have to “chaperone”
a foreign delegation and will have more time for the rest of your friends
here to have the pleasure the “extranjeros” enjoyed last time,
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell, Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
P. S. Have you seen Sir Arthur Newsholme's book, “The Story of Modern
Preventive Medecine?” Its just out (1929). He very kindly sent me a
complimentary copy, as did Dr. Hoff[unclear]man, of the Prudential his book on
“Malaria Problems,” dedicated to Father, Gorgas et. al. However, I think
I told you of this latter one. Haven't had time to read either of them,
nor will I until I finish the work on the book.
